model.hed: Top 20 Hotels in Florida: Readers' Choice 2013
model.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate the top hotels in Delray Beach, Orlando, Key West, St. Augustine, Fort Lauderdale, South Beach, Islamorada, Miami, South Beach, and Palm Beach

memberComments.comment: "Quaint, quiet and good location."
"Just about perfect. Lovely pool, great restaurant, helpful staff. We love staying in this property."
"We were there for the BCS National Championship Game in January 2013. Normally excellent Ritz Carlton service was elevated to an even higher level. Outstanding!"
"The Grand Bohemian is a fabulous hotel—a feast for the senses. The decor and art are fabulous. The pianos and food are wonderful. Downtown Orlando has things to do."
"Very cool hotel. Had a lot of ambiance!"
"Great for business and shopping."
"Friendly staff and great set up. Golf within a few feet from your room. Huge pool to enjoy with refreshment stand serving something to keep you cool."
"Welcome to paradise! Everything you ever dreamed of in a hotel - and all on two floors."
"From the decor to the food to the service and the staff, this hotel has done it up right and continues to serve it's clients the best of everything in sumptuous style."
Wonderful old world flavor and convenient to everything--park your car and enjoy St. Augustine.
Loved the antiques and original artwork in this renovated historic hotel.  Great service. Location was perfect for exploring the oldest city in the US.
This one's a real beauty.  Accommodations are well above average.  The roof top bar is spectacular!

I stayed at EPIC Hotel for about a week and thought it was absolutely the best. Free computer use (apparently there is one in every room), luxury service, great dining, great spa, great pool deck, great location.
Day Manager, Roman, was the BEST! Extremely helpful with dining and activity suggestions; handled excursion bookings. Tasty & generous breakfast buffet.  Nice mix of guests.

Elegant, with an island vibe.  Small and intimate. Brick paths through tropical gardens: orchids, orchids, orchids! Chat with Toby, the resident cockatiel.  Charming, helpful, friendly staff.  And only a short walk to the action on Duval Street.
Would gladly go back. Loved the music playing in our room when we arrived, the staff was attentive, and views of the Intracoastal Waterway were gorgeous.
Lovely suite with a gorgeous view water and boats. Pool is shaded by nearby buildings, but the beach is nearby for Florida sunshine.
Nice location and very private.

We had a suite on the 2nd floor and loved it. Dining on the pier was wonderful and the food pretty terrific. We plan to be back in 2012 and have decided it is the only place we want to stay in Ft. Lauderdale.
A delightful, polished, intimate gem directly on the Intracoastal waterway.   The sunsets over the waterway are magic.
Very nice hotel. Great pool area and beach services. Excellent hotel staff.
Fun, lively pool area and easy access to the Lincoln Avenue Mall.

The Seagate Hotel and Spa has recently moved  from its old 'across from the beach' location to a spot in town. The location is about a mile from their 'Beach Club,' though the ocean is visible from the upper floor rooms on the east side of the hotel.  The hotel provides regular 'jitney' transportation to the beach.  The bar is a local Delray hot spot.  All is beautifully decorated, with huge, spectacular aquariums in the lobby.  Hotel service is friendly and professional.

The Seagate was a wonderful experience.  The restaurant was top notch.  The location is excellent.  The staff was friendly and the rooms were roomy and spotless.  I loved the ocean area and the facilities were excellent.
Unbelievable design that goes over the top in a very good way. This place is what I want a hotel experience to be like.
The staff is incredible! We stayed that night of our wedding and it was 5-star service all around. The room was incredible and the views from our balcony breathtaking.
The rooms are so cozy and comfortable. The pools are excellent. Great service. The breakfast in the restaurant was very good. The best desserts in Orlando!
Wow!  Beautiful grounds.  The staff couldn't do enough to make our stay wonderful.

items.name: Island City House Hotel, Key West
Brazilian Court Hotel & Beach Club
items.description: Built in 1926 and recently renovated, this Palm Beach landmark is made up of lush courtyards and classic Spanish-Mediterranean architecture. The location is within walking distance of “great shopping” on Worth Avenue, a block away. Rooms come with mahogany crown molding, Provence-style wood shutters, oil-rubbed bronze fixtures, and king-size beds. “I feel like I have arrived at home when I check in, the staff are so welcoming.” The French-American menu at Café Boulud is “always excellent”; take lunch on its outdoor patio or a pre-dinner cocktail in its lounge, where “the ambience is delightful.”

items.name: EPIC Miami
items.description: You’ll find this hotel, in an elliptical 52-story mixed-use building of curved glass, "just the right distance from the craziness"—it sits where the Miami River meets Biscayne Bay. Designed by Cheryl Rowley, "spacious rooms are real beauties" in neutral beiges and whites, and are highlighted by floor-to-ceiling glass doors leading to private balconies. Area 31, on the sixteenth floor, serves Mediterranean-inspired seafood, and the "sommelier is exceptional." London-based Zuma brings its Japanese cuisine to a space on the first floor. Exhale Spa looks out over the city and has a treatment menu with massages, core conditioning, acupuncture, and yoga. "The rooftop bar is spectacular."

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Miami
items.description: Like a computer playing Liszt, this 221-room tower—the city’s tallest at 70 stories—is a technically flawless classical composition. Its failing is that Miami moves to a Latin beat. Rooms are so cookie-cutter luxe that you’ll have to open the drapes to determine where you are, and its all-business location at the edge of the Financial District is inconvenient to the beach. But as a place to hole up, you can’t do much better than the Four Seasons. A two-acre terrace on the seventh floor has three swimming pools and an alfresco bar/restaurant; at 50,000 square feet, the gym is bigger than many hotels, and a ten-treatment-room spa and full-service salon are the last word in pampering. The food is impeccable, as are the staff, who are at your side, unbidden, should you so much as break stride to remember where you’re heading. The hotel is especially accommodating of children, with wading pools and a kids-only room service menu that is both varied and a good value (most items are priced from five to nine dollars).

fields.title: four-seasons-miami-pool.jpg
fields.credit: Courtesy Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts

items.name: Il Lugano, Fort Lauderdale
items.description: Stroll to the Intracoastal Waterway or Atlantic Ocean—two blocks away—from this contemporary hotel near Las Olas Boulevard. The 15-floor property ushers guests into a chandelier-clad lobby done in Venetian plaster. The "amazing rooms have gorgeous panoramic views," and "we loved the music coming from the Bose speakers when we entered." With views of the ocean and waterway, the "excellent though expensive" Da Campo Osteria serves Italian fare, including scallops puttanesca with grape tomatoes, capers, and Kalamata olives, and a flatbread of seasonal mushrooms, fontina, and truffle oil. "The staff were attentive, and the food and drinks were delicious." This "perfect getaway" includes perks of private dockage for yachts up to 50 feet and complimentary transport to nearby attractions in a Cadillac Escalade.

fields.title: Il Lugano Suite Hotel
fields.caption:
**


 Overall score: 89.8**


See full rating information for **[Il Lugano Suite Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/il-lugano-suite-hotel-fort-lauderdale-fort-lauderdale-florida)**

items.name: Mandarin Oriental, Miami
items.description: "Far from the madding crowd," this Brickell Key hotel with a curved facade overlooking Biscayne Bay is "a spectacular alternative to Miami Beach." Interiors combine "sophisticated Florida decor with Asian influences." All guest rooms have balconies with bay or skyline views—"we saw a manatee in the water below from our balcony"—and beds with Anichini linens that afford "amazing slumber each night." At the waterfront Azul, dine on modern European cuisine with American and Asian accents; Café Sambal has a full sushi menu. "The service is outstanding—ask someone where the elevator is and they will escort you there instead of just pointing." The spa is outfitted with bamboo, rice paper, golden stones, and natural linens, and offers treatments like a ginger, mandarin, and frankincense body scrub that is "to die for."

fields.caption: Readers say "the spa is to die for," and that the rooms "have some of the best decor ever."  Amenities here are rated as "high quality," specifically the "great food and beverages," the "mini beach," and the great service and great staff."
fields.title: Mandarin Oriental Miami

items.name: Marquesa Hotel
items.description: "It’s like paradise within Key West." In the center of the city’s historic district, a block from Duval Street and five blocks from the Gulf of Mexico, this hotel is within walking distance of the main tourist sights and museums yet remains "a quiet oasis right in the middle of everything." Originally built in 1884 as a private home, the "magically addictive" Greek Revival–style property now includes additional wood buildings with porches, peaked metal roofs, gingerbread trim, and pastel-colored exteriors, all set around a courtyard and two pools. "Eighteen visits in 16 years, and the only reason there haven’t been more is that I can’t squeeze any more time off to get here." Rooms in light yellows, blues, and grays have hand-carved agathis-wood sleigh beds from Indonesia, planter’s chairs from the West Indies, teak tables from the Philippines, and yew armoires from England. The dinner-only, stone-floor Café Marquesa serves a different contemporary American menu daily, but black grouper, yellowtail snapper, and Key West shrimp are often represented.

items.name: The Moorings Village & Spa
items.description: On the site of a former coconut plantation midway between Miami and Key West, this 18-acre "Old Florida–style property" gets a perfect location score for its setting on 1,100 feet of private white-sand beach, amid bougainvillea and 700 coconut palms. "Very private cottages" range from one to three bedrooms in size, with kitchens and hardwood floors, and, in many cases, washers and dryers. Pierre’s Restaurant is a white two-story plantation house with blue shutters; diners can eat inside or out with views of Florida Bay sunsets. The spa offers massages, skin treatments, facials, yoga, and reflexology.

fields.caption: **Our readers say**: On the site of a former coconut plantation midway between Miami and Key West, this 18-acre "Old Florida–style property" gets a perfect location score for its setting on 1,100 feet of private white-sand beach, amid bougainvillea and 700 coconut palms. "Very private cottages" range from one to three bedrooms in size, with kitchens and hardwood floors, and, in many cases, washers and dryers. Pierre’s Restaurant is a white two-story plantation house with blue shutters; diners can eat inside or out with views of Florida Bay sunsets. The spa offers massages, skin treatments, facials, yoga, and reflexology.
fields.title: [Moorings Village Islamorada](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/moorings-village-islamorada-islamorada-florida)

items.name: Pillars Hotel, Fort Lauderdale
items.description: Situated on New River Sound, a block from the beach, this classic Art Deco hotel is "a delightful, polished, intimate gem directly on the Intracoastal Waterway. The sunsets here are magical." British colonial–style guest rooms and suites, done in soft greens and yellows, with dark woods and black-and-white pictures by a local artist, are "comfortable, not pretentious." Marble bathrooms have Molton Brown amenities. "Dining dockside is wonderful, and the food is pretty terrific"—American cuisine with Moroccan accents, courtesy of the Moroccan chef.

items.name: The Seagate Hotel & Spa
items.description: Those who will consider only a hotel smack on the sand are likely to temper their convictions after a stay at the Seagate, set two blocks west of the ocean on bustling Atlantic Avenue in Delray Beach. True, you’ll have to walk five minutes (or hop on the complimentary trolley) before you can stick a toe in the surf, but that’s assuming you’ll want to leave the hotel. For what little the Seagate lacks in proximity to the beach, it more than makes up for in comfort and service. A marine decor dominates the public areas, with three massive aquariums filled with jellyfish and exotic eels on the ground floor, and sculptural light fixtures inspired by seashells and corals. The 156 rooms don’t win points for originality; their dark-wood-and-neutral palette recalls a furnished executive studio. But they’re comfortable and uncommonly large, with sitting areas, wet bars, breezy balconies, and bathrooms with tubs built for two. The staff is eager to please and the hotel’s beach club is the perfect spot for lunch between laps in the pool. Apart from the beach and a welcoming spa, daytime diversions can be found in the many shops along Atlantic Avenue, which heats up at night.

items.name: The Setai, Miami Beach
items.description: "The Setai sets the standard for luxury, calm, and taste" in South Beach. "It’s fabulously located in the heart of the action but exudes a tranquillity that takes effect immediately on entering." The 1930s Art Deco main building and modern glass tower have "Asian-inspired accents" throughout. The "gorgeous decor" in rooms includes Chinese jade pieces, teak walls, black granite, and fine silk. The penthouse has a private reserve wine collection, an infinity pool, a whirlpool, and a baby grand piano. The staff are "so hip and discreet" and provide "drinks, towels, and little spray cans of water" at the three pools, each a different temperature.

items.name: King & Grove Tides South Beach
items.description: This Kelly Wearstler–designed "chic icon" of Art Deco architecture on Ocean Drive, formerly called The Tides, is "first-class all the way." Each of the "modern and beautiful rooms" has a panoramic view of South Beach—some via private balconies—headboards and sofas in a mix of pastels, light-shaded woods, marble bathroom countertops, and finished-driftwood tables. Large chandeliers, oversized velvet chairs, textured woods, and metallic accents of brass, bronze, and nickel fill La Marea; its menu showcases local produce and seafood. "The personalized service was top-notch."

items.name: Viceroy Miami
items.description: Interiors maven Kelly Wearstler is giving Miami financial district stalwarts the Mandarin Oriental and the Four Seasons runs for their money with the Viceroy Group’s Brickell Avenue condo-hotel. Guests sprawl on tasteful green- and white-striped loungers with tasty snacks like spicy beef empanadas by day, and the lounge morphs into the post-work go-to for banker types by night. The 162 rooms are done up in classic Wearstler style with Asian inflections: A stork print hangs above the four-poster bed, Chinese-style lamps sit on an onyx desk, and there are azure leather armchairs and black marble floors. Double rooms have kitchenettes and vast walk-in showers. The Viceroy complex is spread over three towers, with the hotel and most facilities in one, the stunning spa in another, and residences filling the third. This layout can lead to confusing navigation: To access the fiftieth-floor pool area, which has jaw-dropping views of Biscayne Bay, you have to switch elevators on the fifteenth floor, where the enormous outdoor pool and the attractive Deco-style restaurant with its good pan-American menu are situated. And despite the fact that this is for all intents and purposes a business hotel, the in-room Wi-Fi service is spotty.

items.name: Waldorf Astoria Orlando
items.description:
This hotel inside the gates of Disney World is "the latest grande dame in town." Expect "amazing personalized service, yet staff are so family-friendly." Art Deco guest rooms are "cozy, comfortable, and pristine" and have dark-wood furniture with satin nickel accents and yellow, teal, and tangerine color schemes. "Staff did more than enough to make our stay wonderful." Seafood and certified Angus beef prime cuts are served at Bull & Bear; Aquamarine offers poolside kid-friendly fare such as flatbread pizzas and frozen-fruit kebabs. Find "complete relaxation" in an aromatherapy body wrap at the 24,000-square-foot Guerlain spa.

When the youngster in you wants theme parks, but the adult in you craves caviar, this newbie inside the Walt Disney World gates fits the bill.

Less than 20 minutes from the Orlando airport, the hotel offers guests free lifts to the Disney theme parks and Downtown Disney. Most of your crew can probably get away without renting a car.

Jane McLean leads up a full-time event team that organizes 50 or so weddings a year and will help locate everything from a minister to a Rolls-Royce. They recommend that you bring in your own wedding planner, though it’s not required.

As smooth and sumptuous as a satin gown, the Waldorf’s glassy pools, polished marble floors, and velvet golf greens are just what you’d expect from the newest outpost of the legendary New York hotel.

The resort’s 25,000-square-foot island overlooks waterways and golf greens, and couples love it for weddings-in-the-round. If you’ve got a big crowd, usher them onto the outdoor promenade for drinks, then scoot inside to the massive ballroom. There are assorted lawns and restaurants—Peacock Alley, Bull & Bear, Oscar’s—for smaller gatherings. And at all the venues you’ve got a waitstaff in white gloves and tails serving your custom-designed menu. On the day of the wedding, the bride and groom are provided with a personal butler, who’ll run last-minute errands, keep track of your bouquet, and wield a serious lint brush.

Bonfires are hot, and so is Florida in August. Instead of roasting marshmallows, drink your favorite camping treat poolside. The Frosty S'mores blends Absolut Vanilla, Frangelico, graham cracker, marshmallow, and ice cream. Prefer dessert straight up? The S'mores Martini shakes up Irish cream, Godiva chocolate liqueur, and Absolut Vodka; it's all served in a glass rimmed with chocolate and crushed graham cracker, and garnished with marshmallows.
